subject: probability
statementHtml: Find the number of permutations of n distinct objects taken k at a time with repetition allowed.
hints: Think about how many ways you can choose the first object, then the second, and so on.
Consider the case when k is equal to n.
Use the formula for permutations without repetition as a starting point.
solutionHtml:
The number of permutations with repetition is given by the formula:

\(\frac{n+k-1}{k-1} \choose n\).

Here, we use the convention that n choose k means the number of ways to choose a set of size k from a set of size n.

",

subject: probability
title: Permutations with Repetition
contentHtml: When we have repeated elements in a set, we need to account for the different arrangements of these elements.

problem.statementHtml: Find the number of permutations of the letters {a, b, c} taken 3 at a time with repetition allowed.
hints: Think about how many ways you can arrange each letter.
Consider the total number of possible arrangements and divide by the number of repeated elements.
Use the formula for permutations to solve this problem.
problem.solutionHtml:
To find the number of permutations, we use the formula P(n,r) = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!}, where n is the total number of elements and r is the number taken at a time.

In this case, n = 3 (the letters {a, b, c}) and r = 3 (we're taking 3 at a time). Since repetition is allowed, we don't need to divide by any repeated elements.

Plugging in the values, we get P(3,3) = \frac{3!}{0!} = 6.
